reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s decision to focus on “target size” (fragility / narrowness) while bracketing navigation quality and number of attempts. This is somewhat related to the overall thesis (whether mostly-great futures are likely absent deliberate optimization), but it mostly presses on scope/interaction rather than directly undermining the core arguments in Sections 2–3 that many plausible value-functions make eutopia a narrow target. So centrality is limited. Its strength is also limited because the position explicitly frames this essay as addressing only point (1) and later acknowledges that other forces (convergence/compromise/‘gravitational pull’) could guide us to the target; the critique doesn’t show that the essay’s conclusions about fragility/fussiness are false, only that a “full evaluation” must integrate other factors. Correctness is mixed: it’s true that navigation/attempts could interact with a narrow target and affect the all-things-considered probability of reaching eutopia, but it somewhat mischaracterizes the essay as if it claimed only target size matters rather than intentionally analyzing one component. The critique is reasonably clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Dynamic improvements in navigation could offset small target size
